FacilityName: Pilot Chemical Company of Ohio Lockland Plant

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Sulfur Trioxide/Sulfur Dioxide Sulfonation process consists of three production units interconnected to a common Sulfur Trioxide storage tank.



The Sulfur Trioxide storage tank is located inside of a heated and enclosed dike that can contain the entire contents of the tank.  This dike as well as all he Sulfur Trioxide processing equipment is located inside of a concrete wall and covered process building.  Sulfur Trioxide is received in 2,600 gallon tank trucks which are then unloaded to a 7,000 gallon tank in a concrete dike that can contain the entire contents of the tank truck.  All connections to the tank truck are made of hard piping.  The Sulfur Trioxide unloading operators undergo an extensive training program and yearly certification is required.



The Sulfur Dioxide storage tank is located in a covered, outside, concrete dike that can contain the entire contents of the tank.  Sulfur dioxide is received in 3,500 gallon tank trucks which are then unloaded in a concrete dike that can contain the entire contents of the tank truck.  Sulfur Dioxide unloading is infrequent and has not occurred in the past 5 years.



Sulfur Dioxide detectors are placed in 12 strategic locations throughout the process building and storage areas.  The detectors activate both visual and audible alarms at the control station.



All processing vessels are designed and tested to ASME codes and fitted with relief systems. Each relief valve is installed downstream of a rupture disk to effect isolation from the process chemicals.  All positive displacement type pumping systems are fitted with internal or bypass type relief valves.



All production units are computer-controlled utilizing a PLC system with equipment interlocks. These interlocks prevent inadvertent startups and allow for orderly shutdown in the event of loss of power, instrument air, steam or other process upsets.  All process equipment and valves are designed to shut down to a safe condition.  All critical process parameters utilize alarming routines through the control system that activates both visual and audible alarms in the control station. Some critical process monitors can trigger an automated shutdown to the safe condition.



An emergency shutdown system stops transfer pumps, closes isolation and control valves and sounds an audible alarm thus limiting the amount of a toxic release and alerting personnel of an emergency situation.  The emergency shutdown system can be activated by pressing a conspicuously marked red palm button in any one of three locations in the process building.  The SO3 unloading process includes a separate emergency shutdown system that closes isolation valves at the unloading station and switches power off to the truck pump. Training on the use of the emergency systems occurs at least once a year.



All production units are registered under International Standard Organization ISO 9001:2008 and are in compliance with the OSHA Process Safety Management standard. Process and operating procedure changes are processed under a sophisticated Management of Change and Document Control system that assesses the safety, environmental and technical impacts of a process change.



An operator training program is in place that utilizes a combination of classroom training and demonstration of competency with evaluation by written test and observation. Operators receive training on new and revised operating procedures as well as personal safety and process safety topics.



The mechanical integrity of the process and control equipment, relief systems and instrumentation is maintained by preventive maintenance and equipment calibration programs.

The D-300 Sulfur Trioxide Sulfonation process consists of one production unit interconnected to a Sulfur Trioxide storage tank.



The Sulfur Trioxide storage tank is located inside of a heated and enclosed dike that can contain the entire contents of the tank.  This dike as well as all the Sulfur Trioxide processing equipment is located inside of a concrete wall and covered process building.  Sulfur Trioxide is received in 2,600 gallon tank trucks which are then unloaded to a 7,000 gallon tank in a concrete dike that can contain the entire contents of the tank truck.  All connections to the tank truck are made of hard piping.  The Sulfur Trioxide unloading operators undergo an extensive training program and yearly certification is required.



All processing vessels are designed and tested to ASME codes and fitted with relief systems.  Each relief valve is installed downstream of a rupture disk to effect isolation from the process chemicals.  All positive displacement type pumping systems are fitted with internal or bypass type relief valves.  There are four sulfur trioxide detectors with audible alarm in the processing area as well as external notification system.



The Sulfur Trioxide flow rate and quantity to the production unit is computer-controlled utilizing a PLC system with equipment interlocks.  These interlocks prevent inadvertent startups and allow for orderly shutdown in the event of loss of power, instrument air or other process upsets.  All process equipment and valves are designed to shutdown to a safe condition.  All critical process parameters utilize alarming routines through the control system that activates both visual and audible alarms in the control station.



An emergency shutdown system stops transfer pumps, closes isolation and control valves and sounds an audible alarm thus limiting the amount of a toxic release and alerting personnel of an emergency situation.  The emergency shutdown system can be activated by pressing a conspicuously marked red palm button in any one of three locations in the process building.  Training on the use of the emergency systems occurs at least once a year.



All production units are registered under International Standard Organization ISO 9001:2008 and are in compliance with the OSHA Process Safety Management standard.  Process and operating procedure changes are processed under a sophisticated Management of Change and Document Control system that assesses the safety, environmental and technical impacts of a process change.



An operator training program is in place that utilizes a combination of classroom training and demonstration of competency with evaluation by demonstration and observation.  Operators receive training on new and revised operating procedures as well as personal safety and process safety topics.



The mechanical integrity of the process and control equipment, relief systems and instrumentation is maintained by preventive maintenance and equipment calibration programs.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The mission of Pilot Chemical is to manufacture chemicals in a safe, efficient and environmentally acceptable manner.  Pilot Chemical holds to the ChemStewards environmental, health, safety and security principles as developed by the Society of Chemical Manufacturers and Affiliates (SOCMA).  Pilot Chemical is also committed to the maintenance of a quality management system which meets the requirements of the International Standards Organization ISO 9001:2008.  This commitment requires the work force to focus on the production of a quality product through continuous improvement in all phases of its operations.



The Pilot Chemical Company of Ohio, Lockland Plant occupies approximately three acres in an open, relatively flat, industrial area, north of Cincinnati, Ohio.  The original facility was constructed in 1964.  The facility produces detergent grade sulfonic acid, synthetic detergents, surfactants and emulsifiers through batch sulfonation and neutralizer systems for use in the industrial and institutional markets.



The regulated substances on site exceeding threshold quantities are Sulfur Dioxide and Sulfur Trioxide, both of which are toxics.



Sulfur Dioxide is a clear, water-white liquid at temperatures below its atmospheric-pressure boiling point of 14 deg. F.  Sulfur Dioxide is stored on site as a liquefied, compressed gas at a pressure near 100 psi.  Sulfur Dioxide vapors are colorless and heavier than air, but are extremely irritating and suffocating at concentrations above 30 ppm.  With a distinctive rotten egg smell, Sulfur Dioxide has good warning properties with an odor threshold of 0.5 ppm.  Sulfur Dioxide is stable and non-flammable in either the gaseous or liquid state.



Sulfur Trioxide is a clear, colorless, oily liquid at temperatures between its freezing and boiling points, which are 90 deg. F and 113 deg. F, respectively.  Sulfur Trioxide has a strong irritating odor and is very hygroscopic, reacting violently with water.  Sulfur Trioxide f

umes react with the moisture in the air to form a dense, white cloud of Sulfuric Acid mist.  This mist is extremely irritating to the eyes, skin and respiratory system.



Residences are at least 600 feet from the main building containing the sulfonation processes and from the Sulfur Dioxide and Sulfur Trioxide storage tanks.



This facility has in place an accidental release prevention program that complies with all of the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management standard.  In addition:

? Sensitive Sulfur Dioxide and Sulfur Trioxide vapor detection systems are installed with monitors located in strategic locations throughout the processing areas to alert plant personnel of leaks.

? The facility is subject to safety inspections by the Lockland Fire Department and our insurance company.

? Before beginning any maintenance operation involving hot work, a Hot Work permit must be completed and signed by both production and engineering.

? The computer-controlled processes are "Fail safe" and include emergency shutdown capability that close isolation valves and stop chemical transfers to effectively limit the amount and extent of a release.  Instruments continuously monitor pressure, temperature and level in critical process vessels and automatically alarm if a parameter exceeds acceptable ranges.  Equipment interlocking is utilized to prevent operation under unsafe conditions.

? An operator training program is in place that utilizes a combination of classroom training and demonstration of competency with evaluation by written test and observation.  Operators receive training on new and revised operating procedures as well as personal and process safety.

? All incidents and recognized near-misses are investigated, including very small drips and leaks, and actions are taken to prevent recurrence.

? A mechanical integrity program is in place which includes equipment preventive maintenance schedules, vessel thickness testing, relief system inspections and in

strumentation calibration.

? Pre-startup reviews are held prior to starting new or modified equipment per OSHA standards.

? Routine audits of operating procedures and work instructions are conducted to assure that safe practices are followed.

? Plant security is in place to restrict unauthorized access to the facility and the chemicals of interest.



This facility has had no recordable accidents with off-site consequences within the past 5 years.   



Because quick response is necessary to minimize the likelihood of onsite or offsite injuries in the event of a chemical accident, an extensive emergency response plan is in place.  In addition to the written plan:

? All employees receive annual training on the use of the emergency response and evacuation plans, use of personal protective equipment, operation of fire extinguishers and spill mitigation techniques.

? Currently, seven plant personnel are trained at the 40 hour industrial emergency responder Technician level.  Each technician receives annual refresher training.

? The facility has a working relationship with the Lockland Fire Department.

? Emergency response drills are performed regularly.

? Emergency response equipment is on site.

? A plant wide emergency notification system is in place.
